title: 110_hr6216
content: The "Asset Management Improvement Act of 2008" is the short title of this Act. It includes revisions to asset management rules and related fees. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development cannot restrict management and related fees for public housing projects unless deemed unreasonable by the public housing agency. Any restrictions must be determined through a negotiated rulemaking process and cannot be effective before January 1, 2011. Compliance with asset management requirements is not affected by fee restrictions. Any public housing agency with fewer than 500 units may choose to be exempt from asset management requirements set by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. If exempt, the agency can maintain the same number of public housing units. The public housing agency, if exempt from asset management requirements, can keep the same number of public housing projects for operating fund allocation. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development is prohibited from restricting the use of Capital Fund assistance by public housing agencies for central office costs. Additionally, tenant participation is required. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must not impede public housing agencies from using Capital Fund assistance for central office costs. Tenant participation and opportunities in public housing must be upheld, even in cases of agencies in receivership. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development encourages resident participation in asset management and local policy development for public housing agencies, as outlined in part 964 of title 24 of the Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 5. INELIGIBILITY OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS FOR ASSISTANCE. Immigrants unlawfully present in the US are ineligible for financial assistance under this Act, as defined by section 214 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1980. Nothing in this Act changes the restrictions in section 214. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development cannot accept management fees for enforcing agreements that prohibit or require registration of legal firearms for personal protection or sport. Additionally, amendments are made to terminate tenancy and assistance for illegal firearm use in federally assisted housing. Amendments are made to terminate tenancy and assistance for illegal firearm use in federally assisted housing by adding new paragraphs and modifying existing ones. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 9, 2008.
